description: This document describes and prioritises gaps for the support of Adlam on the Web and in eBooks. In particular, it is concerned with text layout. It checks that needed features are supported in W3C specifications, in particular HTML and CSS and those relating to digital publications. It also checks whether the features have been implemented in browsers and ereaders. This is a preliminary analysis.
title: Adlam Gap Analysis

description: This document describes requirements for the layout and presentation of text in languages that use the Arabic script when they are used by Web standards and technologies, such as HTML, CSS, Mobile Web, Digital Publications, and Unicode.
title: Text Layout Requirements for the Arabic Script

description: This document summarizes the text composition requirements in the Chinese writing system. One of the goals of the task force is to describe the issues in the Chinese layout requirements, another one is to provide satisfactory equivalent to the current standards (i.e. Unicode), also to promote vendors to implement those relevant features correctly.
title: Requirements for Chinese Text Layout -

description: This document contains proposals for new features to be added to HTML to support bidirectional text in languages such as Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, Thaana, Urdu, etc.

description: This document provides definitions for various terms related to W3C internationalization.
title: Internationalization Glossary

description: This document describes the basic requirements for Indic script layout and text support on the Web and in eBooks. These requirements provide information for Web technologies such as CSS, HTML and SVG about how to support users of Indic scripts. The current document focuses on Devanagari, but there are plans to widen the scope to encompass additional Indian scripts as time goes on.
title: Indic Layout Requirements

description: This document describes requirements for the layout and presentation of text in languages that use the Tamil script when they are used by Web standards and technologies, such as HTML, CSS, Mobile Web, Digital Publications, and Unicode.
title: Tamil Layout Requirements

description: This document provides a checklist of internationalization-related considerations when developing a specification. Most checklist items point to detailed supporting information in other documents. Where such information does not yet exist, it can be given a temporary home in this document. The dynamic page Internationalization Techniques: Developing specifications is automatically generated from this document.
title: Internationalization Best Practices for Spec Developers

description: Describes requirements for general Japanese layout realized with technologies like CSS, SVG and XSL-FO. The document is mainly based on a standard for Japanese layout, JIS X 4051, however, it also addresses areas which are not covered by JIS X 4051.
title: Requirements for Japanese Text Layout ()

description: This document describes requirements for general Korean language/Hangul text layout and typography realized with technologies like CSS, SVG and XSL-FO. The document is mainly based on a project to develop the international standard for Korean text layout. It is similar in intent to the Japanese Layout Requirements WG Note.
title: Requirements for Hangul Text Layout and Typography :

description: This document describes numbering systems used by various cultures around the world and can be used as a reference for those wishing to create user-defined counter styles for CSS.
title: Ready-made Counter Styles

description: This document looks at a number of use cases involving ruby, and examines the pros and cons of a number of alternative approaches for meeting those use cases using the current HTML5 model, the XHTML Ruby Annotation model, and two other models. The aim is to clarify which use cases are supported by the existing markup models (HTML5 or XHTML), and where they are not, provide suggestions about how the markup model could be adapted to support those use cases. Implementers and standards developers can then take this background information and the suggestions in this document to specify and implement a comprehensive markup model for ruby in HTML5.
title: Use Cases & Exploratory Approaches for Ruby Markup

versions.title: Use Cases & Exploratory Approaches for Ruby Markup
Use Cases & Exploratory Approaches for Ruby Markup
Use Cases & Exploratory Approaches for Ruby Markup

description: A simple set of rules for placement of Ruby text in Japanese typography.
title: Rules for Simple Placement of Japanese Ruby

versions.title: Rules for Simple Placement of Japanese Ruby

description: This document describes the best practices for identifying language and base direction for strings used on the Web. The concepts in this document are applicable any time strings are used on the Web, either as part of a formalised data structure, but also where they simply originate from JavaScript scripting or any stored list of strings.
title: Strings on the Web: Language and Direction Metadata

versions.title: Strings on the Web: Language and Direction Metadata
Strings on the Web: Language and Direction Metadata
Strings on the Web: Language and Direction Metadata

description: Discusses some of the problems encountered when working with the date, time, and dateTime values from XML Schema when those value include (or omit) time zone offsets. Many W3C technologies rely on date and time types.
title: Working with Time Zones

description: This document describes requirements for the layout and presentation of text in the Tibetan script for use with Web standards and technologies, such as HTML, CSS, Mobile Web, Digital Publications, and Unicode. In addition to Tibet and China, the script is widely used in Bhutan, Nepal, India and throughout the Tibetan diaspora, and requirements for these regions are also included in the scope of the document.
title: Requirements for Tibetan Text Layout and Typography

versions.title: Requirements for Tibetan Text Layout and Typography

description: This document points browser implementers and specification developers to information about how to support typographic features of scripts or writing systems from around the world, and also points to relevant information in specifications, to tests, and to useful articles and papers. It is not exhaustive, and will be added to from time to time.
title: Language enablement index

versions.title: International text layout and typography index
International text layout and typography index
International text layout and typography index

description: This document describes requirements for internationalizing Web services.
title: Requirements for the Internationalization of Web Services

versions.title: Requirements for the Internationalization of Web Services
Requirements for the Internationalization of Web Services

description: Describes internationalization usage patterns and scenarios for Web services. Provides additional guidance for implementers of Web service technologies, suggesting methods for dealing with general international interoperability issues in services and service descriptions. Provides a template for Web service designers to implement international capabilities in their services.
title: Web Services Internationalization Usage Scenarios
